theory.intro.oldText: <par>We know how to expand brackets, rewriting <inline-math/> as <inline-math/>. But can we also do the opposite? How do we <term>pull a factor out of brackets</term>? There is a slightly long procedure that always works, but afterwards we also look at a short-cut you can often take.</par>
theory.intro.latestText: <par>A <term>product equation</term> is an equation like <inline-math/> where both sides of the equation only have multiplications/divisions; no additions or subtractions. When we have such an equation, it is helpful to be able to <term>move factors</term> around in the equation. That's what this skill is about. We look at how we do this, and what short-cuts we can take.</par>

theory.steps.oldText: The stepsTo pull a factor out of brackets, like when pulling out of , take the following steps.Simplify all fractions within the brackets, canceling factors where possible. This turns our example into .Check your result by expanding the brackets in your final result. You should wind up with exactly what you started with. And indeed, if we expand the brackets for then we get .Note that there are short-cuts that directly get you the required result, if you have the insights to use them properly.
theory.steps.latestText: The stepsTo move a factor from one side of a product equation to the other, like when moving the factor in the equation , take the following steps.If the factor is in a multiplication, divide both sides of the equation by the factor. Or alternatively, if the factor is being divided by, multiply both sides of the equation by the factor. For the example, we divide by to get .Cancel fraction factors to get rid of the factor that had to be moved. For the example, we turn into .Depending on the situation, it may also be needed to simplify a fraction inside a fraction into a single fraction. For the example, we turn into , which optionally can still be written as .Note that you can also use a short-cut: if a factor is originally multiplied on one side, it will be divided by on the other side, and vice versa.

theory.removingMultiplications.oldText: <head>Getting rid of a multiplication</head><par>One thing that we can do with the equation <inline-math/> is to get rid of the factor <inline-math/> on the left. To do so, we can first <skill-link>divide both sides of the equation</skill-link> by <inline-math/>. This gives <block-math/> Now, both sides of the equation can be simplified. On the left we can <skill-link>cancel fraction factors</skill-link>, where we see that the <inline-math/> indeed disappears from the left side of the equation, as was our goal. On the right, we can <skill-link>simplify the fraction division</skill-link> to get <inline-math/> (or alternatively <inline-math/>). The final result is <block-math/> Note that we have moved the factor <inline-math/> from the left to the right, and when we did, it turned from a multiplication (above) into a division (below).</par>
theory.removingMultiplications.latestText: <head>Getting rid of a multiplication</head><par>One thing that we can do with the equation <inline-math/> is to get rid of the <term>multiplication factor</term> <inline-math/> on the left. To do so, we can first <skill-link>divide both sides of the equation</skill-link> by <inline-math/>. This gives <block-math/> Both sides of the equation can be simplified. On the left we can <skill-link>cancel fraction factors</skill-link> to get rid of the <inline-math/> on both sides of the fraction, leaving us with just <inline-math/>. We see that the <inline-math/> indeed disappears from the left side of the equation, as was our goal. On the right, we can <skill-link>simplify the fraction division</skill-link> to get <inline-math/> (or alternatively <inline-math/>). The final result is <block-math/> Note that we have moved the multiplication factor <inline-math/> from the left to the right, and when we did, it turned into a division factor.</par>

theory.removingDivisions.oldText: <head>Getting rid of divisions</head><par>We could've also done something different with the equation <inline-math/>: get rid of the division by <inline-math/> on the right. To do so, we can <skill-link>multiply both sides of the equation</skill-link> by <inline-math/>. This turns it into <block-math/>. On the right, the division by <inline-math/> and the multiplication by <inline-math/> cancel out, so this reduces to <inline-math/>. The result can be rewritten as <block-math/> Note that we have moved the division by <inline-math/> on the right to the left, where it turned into a multiplication.</par>
theory.removingDivisions.latestText: <head>Getting rid of a division</head><par>We could've also done something different with the equation <inline-math/>, which is to get rid of the <term>division factor</term> <inline-math/> on the right. To do so, we can <skill-link>multiply both sides of the equation</skill-link> by <inline-math/>. This turns it into <block-math/> On the right, the division by <inline-math/> and the multiplication by <inline-math/> <skill-link>cancel out</skill-link>, so this side reduces to just <inline-math/>. The result can be rewritten as <block-math/> Note that we have moved the division factor <inline-math/> from the right to the left, where it turned into a multiplication factor.</par>

theory.shortCut.oldText: The short-cutWe can summarize the above ideas into a useful short-cut. If we move a factor (multiplication or division) from one side of the equation to another, we should do the following.If the factor is above (in a multiplication, or in the numerator of a fraction) then on the other side it will appear below.If the factor is below (in the denominator of a fraction) then on the other side it will appear above (in a multiplication, or in the numerator of a fraction).Using this idea, we can also move factors around without applying the in-between steps.
theory.shortCut.latestText: The short-cutWe can summarize the above ideas into a useful short-cut. If we move a factor (multiplication or division) from one side of the equation to the other, we should do the following.If the factor is a multiplication factor (it's in the numerator of a fraction, or just in a multiplication) then on the other side it will appear as a division factor (in the denominator of a fraction). So turns into .If the factor is a division factor (in the denominator of a fraction) then on the other side it will appear as a multiplication factor (in the numerator of a fraction, or just in a multiplication). So turns into .Using this idea, we can also directly move factors around, without applying the in-between steps.

equation.onlyOrderChanges.incorrectEquat.latestText: The equation is not equivalent to what was expected. You took a wrong step somewhere in rewriting it.

equation.onlyOrderChanges.oneSideCorrect.latestText: The <check><on-true>left</on-true><on-false>right</on-false></check> side of the equation is correct, but something's wrong on the <check><on-true>right</on-true><on-false>left</on-false></check> side. <check><on-true>You have not done what was required.</on-true><on-false>It's not equivalent to what was expected, so you took a wrong step somewhere.</on-false></check>

equation.onlyOrderChanges.sidesSwitched.latestText: Oops ... you have switched the left and the right side of the equation. Try switching them back!

equation.onlyOrderChanges.oneSideSwitche.oldText: There's a few things wrong here. First of all, you switched the equation sides. And then the <check><on-true>left</on-true><on-false>right</on-false></check> side of the equation (which should be on the <check><on-true>right</on-true><on-false>left</on-false></check>) still isn't what it's expected to be.
equation.onlyOrderChanges.oneSideSwitche.latestText: The <check><on-true>left</on-true><on-false>right</on-false></check> side of the equation is correct, but it should be on the <check><on-true>right</on-true><on-false>left</on-false></check>. The <check><on-true>right</on-true><on-false>left</on-false></check> side of the equation still has some errors you might want to look at.

equation.equivalent.oneSideCorrect.latestText: The <check><on-true>left</on-true><on-false>right</on-false></check> side of the equation is correct, but something's wrong on the <check><on-true>right</on-true><on-false>left</on-false></check> side. You took a wrong step there at some point.

equation.onlyOrderChanges.correctEquatio.latestText: This is not the right answer. The equation itself is correct though. Have you done what was required?

equation.fullFeedback.oneSideCorrect.oldText: The <check><on-true>left</on-true><on-false>right</on-false></check> side of the equation is correct, but something's wrong on the <check><on-true>right</on-true><on-false>left</on-false></check> side. <check><on-true>You have not done what was required.</on-true><on-false>It's not equivalent to what was expected, so you took a wrong step somewhere.</on-false></check>
equation.fullFeedback.oneSideCorrect.latestText: The <check><on-true>left</on-true><on-false>right</on-false></check> side of the equation is correct, but something's wrong on the <check><on-true>right</on-true><on-false>left</on-false></check> side. <check><on-true>You have not done what was required.</on-true><on-false>You took a wrong step somewhere.</on-false></check>
